title: Ranganathittu Bird Sanctuary
short_description: A picturesque bird sanctuary on the banks of the Kaveri river, Karnataka, featuring crocodile-filled waters and nesting islets.
long_description: Ranganathittu Bird Sanctuary (also known as Pakshi Kashi of Karnataka), is located in the Mandya District of the state of Karnataka in India. It is the largest bird sanctuary in the state, only 40 acres in area, and comprises six islets on the banks of the Kaveri River. Ranganathittu is the result of a small dam across the river which created islets where birds began to nest. Noted ornithologist Salim Ali observed that the islets formed an important nesting ground for a large variety of birds, and persuaded the Wodeyar kings of Mysore to declare the area a protected area in 1940. It is a breeding ground for Painted Storks, Pelicans, and Spoonbills.
wildlife_significance: Crucial nesting site for Painted Storks and Spot-billed Pelicans. High density of Marsh Crocodiles.
major_experiences: Boat safari to get close to nesting birds and crocodiles
guides_and_tips: Go early to beat the heat and crowds. The boat ride is short but intensity of sightings is high.
how_to_reach: By Air: Mysore Airport (25 km). By Rail: Srirangapatna (3 km). By Road: 19 km from Mysore.
permits_and_fees: Tickets at gate. Boat tickets purchased inside.
conservation_notes: Flooding of Kaveri sometimes inundates nests; water release from KRS dam is monitored.
sample_itinerary: Half-day: Drive from Mysore. Morning boat ride (30 mins). Walk around the park. Visit Srirangapatna Fort nearby. Lunch at Mayura Riverview.
safety_tips: Do not put hands in water (Crocodiles). Wear life jackets.

opening_hours.time_notes: Boating stops if water level is dangerous.

operating_season.off_season: July to September (Monsoon - boating often cancelled)
operating_season.season_notes: Best time is actually summer when water is low and birds nest.

pricing_metadata.disclaimer: Boat availability depends on water levels.
